hints_html:
Part (i) shows us that the order of a modulo \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\) is equal to \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha}\). Thus each of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

are distinct odd numbers and thus each of the

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-1)a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

are also distinct odd numbers. Hence it suffices to show that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-1)a^{k} \not\equiv a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

for any \(\displaystyle 0 \leq j,k \leq 2^{\alpha}-1\) and finish off the proof with a counting argument.

question: 7 (ii)
sols_html:
Repeating the hint, part (i) shows us that the order of a modulo \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\) is equal to \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha}\). Thus each of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

are distinct odd numbers between 0 and \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\) for \(\displaystyle 0 \leq j \leq 2^{\alpha}-1\) and thus each of the

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-1)a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

are also distinct odd numbers between 0 and \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\). As there are \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha-1}\) total odd numbers between 0 and \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\), we know that provided all of the above numbers are distinct, we have found \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha} + 2^{\alpha} = 2^{\alpha+1}\) total odd numbers and hence we can form a bijection. Hence it suffices to show that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-1)a^{k} \not\equiv a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

for any \(\displaystyle 0 \leq j,k \leq 2^{\alpha}-1\). This shows the claim for all odd numbers since all odd numbers are equivalent modulo \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\) to an odd number between 0 and \(\displaystyle 2^{\alpha+2}\).

Assume towards a contradiction that we found two such numbers:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-1)a^{k} \equiv a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

Without loss of generality, suppose that \(\displaystyle k \geq j\). Then,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle a^{k-j} \equiv -1 \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]

Once again, modulo 4 arguments (recalling that \(\displaystyle a \equiv 5 \mod{8}\)) show that the left hand side above is congruent to 1 modulo 4 and the right hand side is still congruent to -1 modulo 4. This is a contradiction. Thus any odd number can be expressed uniquely of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-1)^{i}a^{j}\end{aligned}\]

with \(\displaystyle i \in \{0,1\}\) and \(\displaystyle 0 \leq j \leq 2^{\alpha}-1\) as required.

statement_html:
Let \(\displaystyle a \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that \(\displaystyle a \equiv 5 \mod{8}\) and let \(\displaystyle \alpha \in \mathbb{N}\).

(ii) For each odd integer x, prove that there exists a unique \(\displaystyle i \in \{0,1\}\) and a unique \(\displaystyle j \in \{0,1,2,...,2^{\alpha}-1\}\) such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x \equiv (-1)^{i}a^{j} \mod{2^{\alpha+2}}\end{aligned}\]
